texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: First, you have to get the certificate and key out of Windows in a pfx (PKCS #12) format.
texts.text: First, you have to get the certificate and key out of Windows in a pfx (PKCS #12) format.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Click Start, Run, then type "mmc" and hit enter.
texts.text: Click Start, Run, then type "mmc" and hit enter.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: In the leftmost menu, choose "Add/Remove Snap In".
texts.text: In the leftmost menu, choose "Add/Remove Snap In".

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Click "Add", then click "Certificates", then OK.
texts.text: Click "Add", then click "Certificates", then OK.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: When the wizard starts, choose "Computer Account", "Local Computer" and finish out the wizard.
texts.text: When the wizard starts, choose "Computer Account", "Local Computer" and finish out the wizard.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Once you're finished, get back to the MMC and expand the "Certificates" node, then the "Personal" node.
texts.text: Once you're finished, get back to the MMC and expand the "Certificates" node, then the "Personal" node.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Click on the "Certificates" node under "Personal" and find your certificate in the right pane.
texts.text: Click on the "Certificates" node under "Personal" and find your certificate in the right pane.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Right click on the certificate and choose "All Tasks", then "Export".
texts.text: Right click on the certificate and choose "All Tasks", then "Export".

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: When the wizard starts, choose "Yes" for exporting the private key, then select
texts.text: When the wizard starts, choose "Yes" for exporting the private key, then select

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Once the PFX file has been saved, close out the MMC (don't save the snap-in if it asks).
texts.text: Once the PFX file has been saved, close out the MMC (don't save the snap-in if it asks).

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Get the PFX over to the Linux server somehow.
texts.text: Get the PFX over to the Linux server somehow.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Once the PFX makes it over to the Linux server, you have to decrypt the PFX into a plaintext PEM file (PFX's are binary files, and can't be viewed in a text editor):
texts.text: Once the PFX makes it over to the Linux server, you have to decrypt the PFX into a plaintext PEM file (PFX's are binary files, and can't be viewed in a text editor):

texts.label: code
texts.orig: openssl pkcs12 -in file.pfx -out file.pem
texts.text: openssl pkcs12 -in file.pfx -out file.pem

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: You will be asked for the password for the PFX (which is the one you set in the Windows wizard). Once you enter that, you will be asked for a new password. This new password is used to encrypt the private key. You cannot proceed until you enter a password that is 4 characters or longer.  REMEMBER  this password!
texts.text: You will be asked for the password for the PFX (which is the one you set in the Windows wizard). Once you enter that, you will be asked for a new password. This new password is used to encrypt the private key. You cannot proceed until you enter a password that is 4 characters or longer.  REMEMBER  this password!

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: When this step is complete, you should have a PEM file that you can read in a text editor. Open the file in a text editor and copy the private key and certificate to different files. Remember to keep the dashed lines intact when you copy the certificates - this is important. There is some additional text above the key, and also between the key and certificate - this text should be ignored and should not be included in the certificate and key files.
texts.text: When this step is complete, you should have a PEM file that you can read in a text editor. Open the file in a text editor and copy the private key and certificate to different files. Remember to keep the dashed lines intact when you copy the certificates - this is important. There is some additional text above the key, and also between the key and certificate - this text should be ignored and should not be included in the certificate and key files.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Now that you have the key and certificate separated, you need to decrypt the private key (or face the wrath of Apache every time you restart the server). You can decrypt the private key like this:
texts.text: Now that you have the key and certificate separated, you need to decrypt the private key (or face the wrath of Apache every time you restart the server). You can decrypt the private key like this:

texts.label: code
texts.orig: openssl rsa -in file.key -out file.key
texts.text: openssl rsa -in file.key -out file.key

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Yes, provide the same file name twice and it will decrypt the key onto itself, keeping everything in one file. OpenSSL will ask for a password to decrypt the key, and this is the password you set when you decrypted the PFX. If you forgot the password, you will need to start over from when you brought it over from the Windows box.
texts.text: Yes, provide the same file name twice and it will decrypt the key onto itself, keeping everything in one file. OpenSSL will ask for a password to decrypt the key, and this is the password you set when you decrypted the PFX. If you forgot the password, you will need to start over from when you brought it over from the Windows box.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: After this entire process, you will have four files, a PFX, PEM, KEY, and CRT. Throw away the PFX and PEM, and you can use the key and certificate files to install into Apache. In case you forget the syntax, here's what goes in the Apache configuration:
texts.text: After this entire process, you will have four files, a PFX, PEM, KEY, and CRT. Throw away the PFX and PEM, and you can use the key and certificate files to install into Apache. In case you forget the syntax, here's what goes in the Apache configuration:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
SSLEngine On
SSLCertificateFile /path/to/your/certificate
SSLCertificateKeyFile /path/to/your/privatekey
texts.text:
SSLEngine On
SSLCertificateFile /path/to/your/certificate
SSLCertificateKeyFile /path/to/your/privatekey
